The Scheme is owned by the Construction Industry Council (CIC) and implemented by the Hong Kong Green Building Council (HKGBC).
The Scheme aims to help consumers, building professionals, and policy makers identify environmentally preferable building materials and products.
The Standard sets out the assessment criteria and their benchmarks for glazing products.
The Standard governs the application and award of a label under the Scheme.
The Standard defines the verification methods.
The Standard determines which labelling grade should be awarded to the product according to the assessment criteria.
This Standard neither modifies nor supersedes laws and regulations.
Compliance with this Standard is not a substitute for compliance with any applicable laws or regulations.
Glazing products are commonly used for fixed and opening windows, window doors, curtain walls, and other elements of the building envelope.
The glazing area of a building serves as an interface to transmit light and provide an outdoor view.
Many glazing products contain substances that may be harmful to the environment and human health.
The greatest environmental impact of glazing products results from energy losses during the building operation stage.
The assessment criteria developed for glazing are to promote the use of energy-efficient building envelopes.
The assessment criteria are to minimize the environmental impact through stringent assessment criteria on the production process and use of materials.
The scope of this Standard is applicable to glass in fixed and opening windows, window doors, and other elements of the building envelope.
Glass blocks and bricks or glass used for internal partitions are excluded from this Standard.
The Scheme is an environmental labelling scheme owned by the Construction Industry Council and implemented by the Hong Kong Green Building Council.
The Standard sets out the assessment criteria and their benchmarks for glazing products to govern the application and award of a label under the Scheme.
The Standard defines the verification methods to determine which labelling grade should be awarded to the product according to the assessment criteria.
Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations is a prerequisite for the manufacturing and marketing of the product.
Glazing products are commonly used building material for fixed and opening windows, window doors, curtain walls and other elements of the building envelope.
The glazing area of a building could account for 10 to 25% of a building's exposed surface, serving as an interface to transmit light and provide outdoor view.
Common types of glazing being used in architectural applications include clear and tinted float glass, tempered glass, and laminated glass as well as a variety of coated glasses.
The greatest environmental impact of glazing products results from the energy losses during the building operation stage due to their long technical service life.

The purposes of the assessment criteria developed for glazing are to promote the use of energy-efficient building envelope and to minimize the environmental impact through stringent assessment criteria on the production process and use of materials.
Each application should specify its types and product series.
One application is only for one product series with the same type of glazing.
Subsequent applications can be made for similar products with different thickness and/or coatings under a labelled product series.
A labelled product series is only eligible for applying within the validity period of the label.
A product to be assessed should meet all the minimum requirements of the 'Core Criteria'.
be awarded a 'Green' Label under the Scheme.

a 'Bronze', 'Silver', 'Gold' or 'Platinum' Label will be awarded according to the total points accumulated.

Table 3 provides benchmarks for grading glazing.
A Platinum grade is awarded for 90 points or above.
A Gold grade is awarded for 80 to 89 points.
A Silver grade is awarded for 70 to 79 points.
A Bronze grade is awarded for 60 to 69 points.
A Green grade is awarded for 50 to 59 points.
No Label is given for below 50 points.

The overall heat transfer coefficient or U-value measures how well a glazing product transfer heat.
A low U-value indicates the glazing product is well insulated, resulting in a reduction of cooling load.
In this Standard, the U-value of the single, double or tripled glazing products shall meet the requirements.
